symptoms_patient_terms: Swollen face or gum near a tooth

differentials.name: Tooth abscess
clues: Severe pain; may be tender to bite
History of deep decay/crack or failed root canal

differentials.name: Pericoronitis (wisdom tooth)
clues: Swollen flap over partly-erupted wisdom tooth

probable_causes: Infected tooth nerve (untreated cavity or crack)
investigations: CBCT if deep space involvement suspected
do_now: Seek urgent dental care (same day if fever or spread)
donts: Do not apply heat to swelling
Do not squeeze or puncture the swelling
Do not delay if fever or swelling is spreading

professional_care.name: Drainage + source control
professional_care.what_it_does: Releases pressure and treats tooth/gum source

professional_care.name: Root Canal (if tooth source)
professional_care.what_it_does: Removes infected nerve to save tooth

professional_care.name: Antibiotics (with systemic signs)
professional_care.what_it_does: Supports control when fever/spread is present
cons: Not a substitute for dental treatment

urgency_modifiers.why: Fever suggests infection is affecting the whole body
Rapidly spreading swelling can threaten airway
Children can deteriorate faster—earlier care is safer
Reduced immunity increases risk of spread

pediatric: Fever or spreading swelling: same-day dental evaluation
Avoid aspirin; use doctor-advised pain relief
systemic_notes: On blood thinners: drainage may need planning—do not stop medicines yourself
Poorly controlled diabetes: infections can spread faster—seek care early

prevention: Maintain gum health (cleaning every 3–6 months if advised)

references.label: ADA Guideline – Antibiotics for Dental Pain and Swelling (2019)
WHO Oral Health – infection and prevention basics
